data.name: Lugano - Unexpected Classic Tour
data.abstract: Past and present: this exceptional tour through classical Lugano is packed with surprises for visitors. Historic figures appear along the way, presenting scenes from the past in entertaining ways.
data.description: This guided walking tour is accompanied by two actors who take on the role of historical characters as they tell the story of the city, bringing the spirit of each era vividly to life. The itinerary takes in a number of historical monuments as well as modern buildings by internationally famous Ticino architects. The “Unexpected Classic Tour” takes place every Monday and is free of charge.

data.name: Lugano and its architecture
data.abstract: From the past to the present: There are a whole host of architectural jewels from the 20th and 21st century to discover on this walk through Lugano.
data.description:
The Ticino architectural tradition has its roots before the year 1000. Maestri Comacini, Intelvesi and Campionesi were born in this region. This tradition was renewed over the centuries.

A guided walk through Lugano gives you the opportunity to discover some of the most interesting buildings built on the shores of Lake Lugano in the 20th and 21st century. From Mario Chiattone to Livio Vacchini, from Rino Tami to Mario Botta, to the local university (USI) campus, our tour will show Lugano in an entirely new light: you’ll be able to admire it from an architect's perspective.

The guided tour is run in collaboration with i2a (Istituto Internazionale di Architettura) and you will be accompanied by a local architect.

data.name: Lugano – Monte San Salvatore
data.abstract: Monte San Salvatore in Lugano offers unique views over Lake Lugano, the Alps and the Po Valley. The funicular takes you to the summit in 12 minutes, where hiking trails, a viewing platform, a museum and a restaurant serving Ticino specialties await you.
data.description:
Monte San Salvatore in Lugano is a top destination for nature lovers and hiking enthusiasts. The funicular railroad takes you quickly and easily from Paradiso to the summit. From the viewing platform, you can enjoy a magnificent view over Lake Lugano, the Alps and as far as the Po Valley.

In the San Salvatore Museum, you can learn exciting facts about the geology and history of the region. Popular hiking trails lead from here to Carona or Morcote. Climbing fans will also get their money's worth on Monte San Salvatore.

The Ristorante Vetta serves typical Ticino dishes, perfect for a break with a view. The mountain is an experience all year round and ideal for a day trip.

data.name: Lake Lugano Cruises
data.abstract: At Lake Lugano, it is wonderfully easy to escape one’s daily routine: by enjoying a sunbath below palm trees, cruises on the lake or hiking tours through magnificent landscapes.
data.description:
Whether culture, nature or excursions into vibrating nightlife, the lake region offers all of it and then some.

A boat cruise is the perfect way to explore the diversity of the region: Morcote with its stately patrician houses and the Santa Maria del Sasso Church, an important renaissance building at a unique panoramic location with a clock tower dating from the late romantic era; or Gandria, the epitome of a quaint little fishing village at the shores of Lake Lugano.FACTS
Route: Lugano – Gandria – Lugano
Duration: app. 2 to 4 h
EXCURSION TIPS
 * Gandria and surrounding area
 * Monte San Salvatore
 * Swiss Customs Museum
 * Swissminiatur – a miniature Switzerland
 * Monte Generoso

FOOD & BEVERAGES
Coffee, tea, pastries, an innovative kitchen and delicious meals with appealing on-board service.TIMETABLE
All connections here [https://www.lakelugano.ch/en]TICKET
This route is fully covered by the Swiss Travel Pass (Flex) and GA travelcard.
Book tickets [https://www.myswitzerland.com/en/planning/transport-accommodation/tickets-public-transport/]
RESERVATIONS
No seat reservation required – free seating.

data.name: Discover the Lugano region the environmentally friendly way
data.abstract: Practical, environmentally friendly and appealing: PubliBike’s bike hire system is the ideal way to explore the area around Lugano without getting stuck in traffic or wasting time looking for a parking space.
data.description:
The environmentally friendly, efficient and healthy solution is captivatingly simple. Bikes are available to hire at 47 locations throughout Lugano and can be easily located using the free PubliBike app. The bikes can be unlocked with a smartphone or a pre-registered SwissPass. Once you’re done, simply return the bike to any PubliBike station. The bikes are available 24/7.

PubliBike [https://www.publibike.ch/en/publibike/]

data.name: Foxtrail – fun in Lugano
data.abstract: In Lugano, the fox takes chasers across the entire Mediterranean-style town. You'll search for secret treasure and will need to rescue knights, decipher ancient lettering and follow traces of blood.
data.description: The fox has laid its trails. Secret messages, hidden clues and many tricky and perplexing challenges show you the way from one stop to the next. You are out on the trail by yourself and never know what’s waiting in store for you – even people familiar with the region are bound to discover new things. The Foxtrail takes you through towns and countryside on foot and using various means of transport. The trails last between 1.5 and 4.5 hours. All you’ll need is good shoes and a mobile phone per group in case you need to call the hotline. Pricing depends on your age and the length of the trail. Simply book online through the website, print the starting instructions and enjoy solving the puzzles!

data.name: A visit to Lugano's parks and gardens
data.abstract: Did you know that Lugano boasts a unique Mediterranean-style climate that allows olive trees, cork oaks and palm trees to flourish side-by-side?
data.description:
A stroll through Lugano’s parks and gardens offers visitors a chance to enjoy the city’s lush greenery, and discover exotic plants and flowers as well as local varieties. The walk begins at the church of Santa Maria degli Angioli, leads through the Belvedere gardens and ends in the Parco Civico-Ciani, the city’s largest park and one of the most important in the whole of Switzerland. 

On one of Ticino’s many gloriously sunny days, nothing beats exploring Lugano’s parks and gardens, ice cream in hand, while enjoying the breathtaking scenery and the delightful Mediterranean climate

data.name: Explore street art in Lugano
data.abstract: This self-guided tour allows you to discover Lugano from the perspective of its street art.
data.description:
The Lugano Street Art Tour gives you the opportunity to explore numerous public works of art that have been created by AUL (Arte Urbana Lugano) and other private institutions over the years. The tour opens up a new and unusual side of Lugano that often goes unnoticed,

covering both the city centre and beyond. In addition to artworks in the city centre, the tour also explores hidden gems off the beaten tourist path, including in the small village of Bré on Monte Bré with its historic rural architecture and Sorengo with its futuristic new buildings.

All you need for the tour are a comfortable pair of shoes and the free Street Art Guide Lugano, which you can print out or open as a PDF on your smartphone or tablet.

data.name: Culinary cruise on Lake Lugano
data.description: On the cruise with Patricia Carminati, guests experience real hospitality on Lake Lugano. In the ship’s galley, they assist the cook in making risotto. Meanwhile, “Captain” Patricia is in charge of creating a pleasant atmosphere aboard – typically Lugano.

data.name: Grotto tour on Lake Lugano
data.abstract: The grotto tour takes you on a culinary tour of discovery by boat. Visitors are taken to the grottos, a kind of tavern, and picked up again two hours later.
data.description:
The idea arose because many of the cosy grottos on the shores of Lake Lugano can only be reached on foot or by boat. The boat sets out directly to Brasato, Polenta and Kerzenschein.

It sails during the summer months, starting in Lugano, then on to Paradiso and further to Grotto Pescatori via San Rocco and Caprino. From there, it’s on to Grotto Elvezia via Gandria and then back to Lugano.
More information [https://www.ticino.ch/en/commons/details/Grotti-Tour/150807.html]

For visitors who want to visit a grotto on foot, the hike from Caprino to Cantine di Gandria along Lake Lugano is highly recommended. A lot of the grottos are along the way and are tempting places to make a stop for a tasty meal or glass of wine.
More information [https://www.ticino.ch/en/itineraries/details/From-Caprino-to-Cantine-di-Gandria-along-Lake-Lugano/138326.html]

data.name: Scenic route above Lake Lugano
data.abstract: The steep chestnut forests of the Sottoceneri region offer the ideal backdrop to a hard day's mountain biking.
data.description:
Discover this for yourself by taking the scenic tour from picturesque Morcote across Monte Arbostora. Sensational views of Lake Lugano will compete with endless single trails for your attention on the second part of the tour. In a word, this tour is a byword for unparalleled biking pleasure in a fabulous landscape. What more could a biker want?

data.name: Emotions fly high above Lake Lugano
data.abstract: Soaring high above Lugano in a hot air balloon and marvelling at the beautiful landscape.
data.description: Peering down upon the beauty of Lugano and its surroundings from a bird’s eye view is an unforgettable experience! The autumnal landscape is especially alluring, when the chestnut trees change colour and nature is steeped in a golden light. But of course the trip is also wonderful at other times of the year. For example, how about a sunrise flight or brunch in the balloon?

data.name: Wine cellar visits & Beer Tastings in Lugano Region
data.abstract: Choose the tasting most agreeable to your palate at one of the producers in the Lugano Region and let yourself be inspired by the various food and wine tasting events offered throughout the year.
data.description:
The local producers [https://www.luganoregion.com/en/see-do/gastronomy-traditions/wine-cellars-and-breweries] are at your complete disposal to organize guided tours and tastings at their farm. During the visits you will have the opportunity to meet different producers and taste the uniqueness of their products and our local products.

Experienced staff will guide you on an unforgettable journey to discover delicious flavours and surprising emotions.

event.location: The participant must reach the winery individually.

data.name: Via Nassa
data.abstract: In the heart of the historic city centre, just behind the lakefront promenade, lies Lugano’s principal shopping street.
data.description:
The chic Via Nassa. With its boutiques, antiquarian bookshops and jewellers’, it elevates window-shopping to an art form; 270 metres of covered arcades make for a shady, pleasant stroll, even in high summer. Mouth-watering food emporia and popular department stores also add to the appeal of Lugano’s top address. 

Most shops on the Via Nassa are open on weekdays to 6.30pm and on Saturdays to 5pm. They are closed on Sundays.

data.name: San Michele Park
data.abstract: The San Michele Park sits high above Lugano and offers spectacular views of the city, the lake and the mountains. The typically southern vegetation is sure to thrill many of its visitors too.
data.description:
This park, with 12,000 square metres of green space, sits in Castagnola, on the slopes of Monte Brè. It is known not only for its beauty but also its wonderful architectural elements: the chapel dedicated to San Michele, the rustic cottage and a number of stone sculptures.

Behind the chapel dedicated to San Michele, you’ll find the main terrace of the park. From this privileged position, you can admire the gulf of Lugano, the lakefront and Monte San Salvatore. The view extends as far as the peaks of the Alps in a variety of shapes and colours that glow incandescent as the sun goes down. On the left-hand side, the view stretches from Melide, Campione and Bissone to the plains of the river Po.

San Michele Park also offers rich vegetation: its paths lead through typical southern vegetation such as wisteria, oleander, oak, elm, hornbeam, ash and laurel trees.

data.name: Ciani Park
data.abstract: Located on the shores of Lake Lugano, this 63,000 square metre park constitutes the city’s green lung. Here you can recover from the hustle and bustle of the city as you walk along paths lined by magnificent centuries-old trees.
data.description:
The paths wind through beautiful flower beds, lined with statues and fountains, and are framed by the meticulously manicured English lawn. The park is divided into two areas. The first area in the vicinity of the Villa Ciani can be reached through the main entrance at the end of the waterside promenade. This area has both the features of an Italian and an English garden: lush flower beds alternate with green spaces and trees and shrubs from all over the world. 

The second area extends from the jetty to the Cassarate River and has a "wilder" and more original character. Here you will find oak, lime, plane and maple trees, all typical representatives of the Ticino forests. Within this forested area there is a children's playground with numerous games for children of all ages. 

The Parco Ciani is also home to various buildings: the Villa Ciani, the Convention Centre, a jetty, the Natural History Museum and the Cantonal Library.

data.name: Photo Spot Swissminiatur
data.abstract: Opened in 1959, Swissminiatur is the largest open-air miniature museum in Switzerland. It is located in Melide on the shores of Lake Lugano. There are more than 100 models of the most famous buildings, monuments and means of transport in Switzerland, all at the unusual scale of 1:25. Traditional methods and innovative processes come together to create genuine miniature masterpieces. Admire precision craftsmanship, faithful to the original and executed with loving care.

Apart from well-known attractions, natural and cultural treasures in hiding along the route are just waiting to be discovered.

data.name: Monte Generoso
data.abstract: At the southern end of Lake Lugano is the 1,704 metre high Monte Generoso. This lofty altitude makes it without a doubt the best mountain for views in the canton of Ticino.
data.description:
The new restaurant “Fiore di pietra” (stone flower) created by the famous architect Mario Botta stands majestically on a rugged plateau on the mountain. Its windows offer breathtaking 360° panoramic views, taking in the lakes, the city of Lugano as well as the Matterhorn and Jungfrau all the way to the Bernina Range.

Nostalgic journey to the summit
A cog railway has been taking visitors up to the peak of Monte Generoso for 125 to enjoy these breathtaking views. It is about 9km long and runs along a magical stretch of mountain scenery in the Monte Generoso nature park. In addition to electric trains, nostalgic modes of transport also use this cog railway line, including the oldest steam train still in operation in Switzerland, built in 1890, and trains from the 1950s. A ride in these trains brings the time of the Belle Époque back to life.

Activities on and around the mountain
There is much to discover on Monte Generoso: Keen hikers can explore the mountain on more than 51km of hiking trails. The Nature Trail and the Ice Pits Nevere are just two of the many hiking paths. The Ice Pits Nevere trail takes hikers to restored ice huts, which were once used to chill milk before it was churned into butter. The brave can marvel at the landscape around Monte Generoso from the air by paragliding from the top. Flights start on Monte Generoso and glide in different directions over the lakes, countryside and towns.

INFORMATION
How to get there:
Drive or take public transportation from Lugano to Capolago-Riva San Vitale, from there take the Monte Generoso mountain train to the top of Monte Generoso.

Sunset:
If you get a chance, don’t miss the sunset in Ticino. It’s a truly spectacular experience.

Food/drink:
The “Fiore di pietra” gourmet restaurant and “Generoso” self-service restaurant will satisfy your hunger and thirst after a leisurely stroll or strenuous hike.

Families:
The “Bear Cave” is about 30 minutes from the “Fiore di pietra” building on the Italian side of the mountain. Some 60,000 years ago, it was home to more than 800 cave bears. The cave's length is 200m, 70m of which have been made accessible to visitors. You need sturdy shoes, hiking gear and a hat to follow in the footsteps of the cave bears.

Please note:
Reduced rate mountain rail ascent with the Swiss Travel Pass / GA travelcard.
Buy your tickets on arrival at the station.

More information about Monte Generoso [https://www.montegeneroso.ch/en]


MOUNTAIN DAY TRIPS
Buy your mountain rail ascent return tickets now

Timetable and tickets [https://www.sbb.ch/en/buying/pages/fahrplan/fahrplan.xhtml?&nach=GenerosoVetta]

additionalDescriptions.description: The Ferrovia Monte Generoso stands out for its exclusive locations, ideal for tasting culinary excellence, celebrating memorable private events or holding impactful corporate meetings. At 1'704 meters above sea level stands the "Fiore di pietra", an architectural gem that has two restaurants inside: one à la carte for high-class gastronomic experiences and one self-service, perfect for convivial moments. In addition, there is also a unique panoramic conference room inside, capable of accommodating up to 80 people and perfectly adaptable to different needs. At the midway station, however, you cannot miss the iconic Bellavista Buffet. This charming grotto offers a cozy setting with about 40 places, also ideal for private events. Here regional, zero-mile cuisine reigns supreme, delighting guests with traditional Ticino dishes.

What better place to begin your life as a couple than on the cogwheel train and the summit of Monte Generoso? Between breathtaking views and boundless valleys, the "Fiore di pietra" offers a fairytale stage for your wedding. With its distinctive architecture and a 360-degree panoramic terrace, every moment is transformed into an unforgettable memory, embraced by nature and the sky. At this magical venue, every detail contributes to making your special day a daydream.

data.name: Ayurveda and spa
data.abstract: An Ayurvedic break for women in an Indian oasis with a view of Lake Lugano.
data.description: The Shalini Ayurveda Centre is located in Carona. In this women-only oasis of peace and quiet, with a view of the lake and Monte Generoso, visitors enjoy treatments from the therapeutic tradition of Kerala. The Indian science and philosophy of Ayurveda deals with all aspects of the human experience, including affectivity and female health. During their stay, the women can enhance their knowledge of health issues, especially topics such as motherhood, periods, sexuality, relationships and feminine energy. The retreat also helps women to live generally more balanced and happier lives.

data.name: Hermann Hesse Foundation
data.abstract: Siddhartha, Narziss and Goldmund or Klingsors letzter Sommer - some of the most important works by Hermann Hesse were written in Montagnola, in the Casa Camuzzi. Today you can visit the Museo Hermann Hesse - located in an idyllic spot above Lake Lugano.
data.description:
Personal objects, photos, books and watercolor paintings tell of the moving life of the German writer Hermann Hesse. During his years in Ticino he wrote with views of the nearby Lake Lugano - in an apartment of the picturesque little castle that went by the humble name of Casa Camuzzi. Besides short stories, some of his most important works - such as Siddharta, Narziss and Goldmund or Klingsors letzter Sommer, were written here. 

Directly by the former dwelling and place of work of the writer, today you discover the Hermann Hesse Museum in the Torre Camuzzi. In addition to the permanent exhibition, here visitors enjoy thematic shows, lectures, concerts, films and readings. And its no wonder that beautiful walks in the surrounding landscape that once inspired the poet and writer also lure people here.

data.name: Lakeshore promenade
data.abstract: The lakeshore promenade in Lugano with its Mediterranean atmosphere is an inviting place for tourists and locals to enjoy a stroll.
data.description:
The promenade is the perfect place to leave the hustle and bustle of everyday life behind and to just be in the moment. 

A walk along the lakeshore promenade takes you through numerous parks including the Belvedere Gardens, where nature and culture form a pleasing blend.

data.name: Monte Lema
data.abstract: Monte Lema is situated between Lake Lugano and Lake Maggiore. At 1,624 metres above sea level, the mountain towers above the Malcantone region and offers panoramic views across southern Ticino and beyond. Monte Lema is the starting point for numerous hikes and bike tours, but also offers culinary highlights and unique views of the stars.
data.description:
Not far from the town of Lugano, in the heart of the Malcantone region, Monte Lema rises to the sky. Easily accessible by cable car, the panoramic view from the upper station is unrivalled. The view extends from the rolling, densely wooded hills of Malcantone with its chestnut forests and picturesque villages to the town of Lugano. If you walk 10 minutes from the upper station to the peak on a clear day, you will be rewarded with a view of the Bernese and Valais Alps.

The restaurant is accessible via a barrier-free path. A spacious terrace and two cosy dining rooms in the restaurant invite you to linger. Typical Ticino dishes are served, ranging from polenta to the famous torta di pane (bread cake). There are also 22 simple beds available in the guest house. A night on the summit is unforgettable.

It is just a short walk from the restaurant to the observatory. During a guided tour, guests can immerse themselves in the vastness of the universe. The stars suddenly seem so much closer. Numerous events are held on Monte Lema during the summer too. For example, a moonlit hike or yoga with a view.

Monte Lema is also the starting point for numerous hikes. Around 80 kilometres of hiking trails are waiting to be discovered. Leisurely circular hikes are ideal for hours of enjoyment. If you are looking for a greater challenge, you can undertake the famous ridge hike to Monte Tamaro. Impressive views are guaranteed. Bikers can expend their excess energy on a wide variety of trails.

Getting there: Take the train from Bellinzona or Lugano to Lamone-Cadempino, bus directly to Miglieglia, cable car to Monte Lema.

DAY TRIPS TO THE MOUNTAINS
Buy your return rail and mountain ascent tickets now

Timetable and tickets [https://www.sbb.ch/de/kaufen/pages/fahrplan/fahrplan.xhtml?&nach=MonteLema]

data.name: Monte Tamaro
data.abstract: The Monte Tamaro lies in the triangle between Lugano, Bellinzona and Locarno. It is famous for the Santa Maria degli Angeli church designed by Mario Botta and the scenic ridge walk from Monte Lema.
data.description:
Leaving from Rivera, the cable car climbs to Alpe Foppa [https://www.myswitzerland.com/en/experiences/food-wine/restaurant/restaurant-alpe-foppa/]at 1,530 metres. The telecommunications mast is a good 300 metres higher, while the actual Tamaro summit is 1,962 metres above sea level. On a clear day you can see the Monte Rosa Massif from the summit and on the Lema hike. There are hiking routes in all directions, and mountain bikers love the downhill routes and the bike park.

The mountain restaurant, the summer toboggan run, the zip wire, the large children’s playground at the upper station and the adventure high ropes park [https://www.myswitzerland.com/en/experiences/suspension-rope-park-of-the-monte-tamaro/]at the middle station combine to make Monte Tamaro a mountain packed with adventure. The Splash & Spa Tamaro [https://www.myswitzerland.com/en/experiences/splash-e-spa-aquapark/]in Rivera, a water park spread across more than 10,000 square metres, is also a real delight for water babies.

Altitude: 1,962 metres 
How to get there: Train from Lugano [https://www.myswitzerland.com/en/destinations/lugano/]or Bellinzona [https://www.myswitzerland.com/en/destinations/bellinzona/]to Rivera-Bironico, 15-minute walk to the valley station, two-stage cable car to Alpe Foppa (1,530 metres) 
Views: To the north across the Magadino plain to Bellinzona, the Ticino mountains to the Gotthard region and the Bernese Oberland; to the south-east the Dent della Vecchia and Monte Generoso [https://www.myswitzerland.com/en/destinations/monte-generoso-and-valle-di-muggio/]
Attractions: Church of Santa Maria degli Angeli [https://www.myswitzerland.com/en/experiences/cappella-santa-maria-degli-angeli/]by Mario Botta, paintings by Enzo Cucchi, summer toboggan run, long zip wire, large playground, adventure park (middle station) 
Food and drink: Alpe Foppa self-service restaurant with seating for 400 
Accommodation: Capanna Tamaro UTOE mountain hut (next to the mast, one hour from Alpe Foppa): 53 sleeping spaces 
Groups: Alpe Foppa: meeting room, seating for 140, traditional cuisine, mainly Ticino specialities such as Ticino polenta with two types of cheese [https://www.myswitzerland.com/en/experiences/food-wine/polenta-ticinese/]
Winter: Closed 
Special comments: Splash & Spa Tamaro water park in Rivera (open all year around)
Discounted mountain ascent with the Swiss Travel Pass [https://www.myswitzerland.com/en/planning/transport-accommodation/tickets-public-transport/swiss-travel-pass/]/GA travelcard.
Buy your tickets on arrival at the station.

data.name: Photo Spot Monte San Giorgio
data.abstract: The Mendrisiotto and southern Lake Lugano region are dotted with highlights. Take, for example, the narrow lanes in the heart of Bissone, home to numerous artists and Francesco Borromini (1599–1667), the “starchitect” of the Renaissance period. The green “pyramid” on the other side of the lake is a UNESCO World Natural Heritage Site: fossils of fish and species of reptiles have been found on Monte San Giorgio, testifying to life on Earth more than 200 million years ago.
data.description:
Address:
Via Maroggia 
6816 Bissone

Parking: 
On left-hand side of the road, subject to a fee

Footpath: 
1 minute, exercise caution when crossing the road

data.name: Piazza della Riforma
data.abstract: Piazza della Riforma in Lugano is the vibrant center of the city, surrounded by historic buildings, cafés and restaurants. Cultural events take place here and the square is the ideal starting point for exploring sights such as Lake Lugano and Parco Ciani.
data.description:
Piazza della Riforma is the lively heart of Lugano and a popular meeting place for locals and tourists alike. The square is surrounded by historic buildings in neoclassical style and provides an impressive backdrop for events and festivals.

Lugano's town hall, an architectural highlight of the city, is located on the piazza. In the summer months, the square is often used for open-air concerts and cultural events. The many cafés and restaurants invite you to relax.

Numerous shopping streets also start here, inviting you to take a stroll. Piazza della Riforma is the ideal starting point for exploring the city center, with sights such as Parco Ciani and Lake Lugano just a short distance away.

Especially in spring and summer, the square is a popular place for a coffee break or an aperitivo in the open air. The good transport links also make the piazza easily accessible for day trippers.

data.name: EGO Gallery
data.abstract: The EGO Gallery at Via Canonica 9 in Lugano was opened to meet a need: it aspires to provide a platform for young artists while at the same time presenting audiences with the latest developments in contemporary art.
data.description: The EGO Gallery originated from an idea held by both Valeria Donnarumma and Giacomo Grandini and is intended to be a meeting place and a point of artistic exchange where art lovers can come up with ideas and inspiration and where they can personally and emotionally engage with today's works of art. The gallery is mainly devoted to Street Art, but in the broadest sense of the term. This project focuses on paying greater attention to young modern artists - young talent as well as established artists - and to supporting new generations of artists. The EGO Gallery is especially noted for its organising of far-reaching projects that involve young local artists.

data.name: Photo Spot Monte Ceneri
data.abstract: Piazza Ticino, on Monte Ceneri Pass, boasts the region’s new landmark – Totem Ticino, which is built of stone from the canton. The symbolism of this work is unmistakable: the piazza represents the union of the three regions of Locarno, Bellinzona and Lugano, whose history was shaped by deep divisions, starting in 1803 – the year in which Ticino became a canton. The totem, on the other hand, represents the completion of the entire AlpTransit project, with the Ceneri Base Tunnel marking the concluding phase. The Totem is clad in stones from Ticino that were removed during the boring of the AlpTransit tunnel. The new Piazza Ticino is one of the main stops on the La Via del Ceneri cultural trail. The oval-shaped space features five benches and four new trees, which offer a shady respite for visitors.
data.description:
Address: Via Monte Ceneri 6802 Rivera

Parking: Parking is available at the petrol station on the pass

On foot: one minute from the petrol station

data.name: Mario Botta – star architect of Southern Switzerland
data.abstract: Mario Botta, the architect from the Ticino, is known around the world. One of his works is the monumental San Francisco Museum of Modern Art (1995). In Lugano, he has left his mark in a number of places.
data.description: One of these places is the former head office of Banca del Gottardo (1987, now Banca della Svizzera Italiana), another the Casino of Campione d'Italia (2007). The latter is visible from the shores of Lake Lugano. Not to be missed is a visit to Monte Tamaro and the Santa Maria degli Angeli church (1996), a masterpiece of contemporary architecture. Botta‘s latest achievement is the bombastic peak restaurant on Monte Generoso, which will open in 2017.

data.name: Palm Express
data.abstract: From the impressive glaciers of Engadin to the lovely palm trees of Lugano: The Palm Express invites visitors to a pleasantly diverse four-hour PostBus journey.
data.description:
After leading over the Maloja pass, the road winds down to the Val Bregaglia. At Astasegna, travellers cross the Swiss-Italian border and little later arrive at the charming Italian town of Chiavenna. The journey’s final destination is Lugano, city of Mediterranean flair and one of Ticino’s main urban areas.
FACTS
Route: St. Moritz – Menaggio – Lugano
Distance: 130 km
Duration: approx. 3.5 h

Important: Passport or identity card required for border crossing to Italy.

FOOD & BEVERAGES
No catering services on the PostBus.TIMETABLE
All connections here [https://postauto.ch/en/leisure/palm-express].TICKET
This route is fully covered by the Swiss Travel Pass (Flex) and GA travelcard.
Book tickets [https://www.myswitzerland.com/en/planning/transport-accommodation/tickets-public-transport/]
RESERVATIONS
Seat reservation required, without surcharge:reservation here [https://postauto.ch/en/leisure/palm-express].

data.name: Riva Caccia Lido
data.abstract: Located in the heart of the city, opposite the Museo d'Arte, Lido Riva Caccia features a floating wooden deck that rocks gently to and fro like a boat.
data.description:
Lake Lugano’s lido offers everything bathers and sun worshippers could ever want: a lakeside pool, diving platform, sun deck, changing rooms, showers and gastronomy. The floating deck affords breathtaking views of the mountains surrounding the lake.

Getting there: By bus nos. 2 and 4 from the train station to “Lugano, Loreto”, bus no. 1 from Paradiso to “Lugano, Malpensata” or by boat to “Lugano, Centrale”, from there it is approx. 1km on foot, there is no parking in the immediate area of the spa.

data.name: Tassino Park
data.abstract: Tassino Park, a glorious haven of peace, is graced with lush vegetation thanks to its sun-drenched position. If you like roses and English-style gardens then this is the place for you. What is now Tassino Park was at one time the hunting lodge of the wealthy Enderlin family, who in the 19th century were the owners of a beautiful villa on the hill of Tassino.
data.description:
Near to Lugano railway station, this 21,000-square metre park features a wide avenue that meanders between hundred-year-old trees and evergreen magnolias up to the pink Enderlin tower.

There, you’ll find a terrace offering wonderful panoramic views: visitors are rewarded with an unforgettable view of Monte Brè, part of the lake, and the city of Lugano.

data.name: Stories of the master sommelier
data.abstract: In 2014, Simone Ragusa was named Swiss master sommelier of the year. Today, you can find him in the “Il Forziere del Vino” wine cellar.
data.description: The wine cellar is the perfect locale for wine tastings and first-rate gastronomic events. It is located in the historic Hotel Splendide Royal in Lugano, where a famous tasting was held in 1981 in honour of the fifty-year anniversary of the Merlot culture in Ticino. The stylishly appointed cellar houses around 500 of the best wines from around the world. Simone Ragusa knows the histories of the various wines and loves to share them at exclusive private events.

data.name: Olive Tree Trail
data.abstract: On the 3.5-kilometer-long "Sentiero dell'olivo" strtetch, 18 information boards bring you closer to the history and scientific nature of olive tree growth and the oil won from olives.
data.description:
A route with views across Lake Lugano, on which a landscape reminiscent of the Mediterranean can be enjoyed. The trail winds between Castagnola and Gandria, passes across the remains of old olive groves and areas on which this prized tree is again being planted. 
Access to the trail is either in Castagnola (near the old community center) or in Gandria (near the parking lot above the village, at the main road). The trail is sign-posted with the olive tree logo and at certain intervals there are display panels.

If you start your tour in Castagnola you will return from Gandria by Porlezza-Lugano bus. The stop is near the Restaurant Gandria. Castagnola as well as Gandria can be reached by means of a Lugano lake cruise ship.

data.name: Dolcefarniente
data.abstract: Rushing from one meeting to the next is not the Ticino way of going about life.
data.description: In Lugano, the parks are too pretty, the alleys of the Old Town too enticing – and the prospect of heading out onto the lake, to soak up the sun and the scenery, too tempting. Whether you opt for a cruise on a scheduled boat or a trip on a pedalo, spend your afternoons in the manner favoured by locals, devoted to “dolce far niente”, the sweet art of doing nothing.

image.name: 0000075652-lugano_16h00.jpg
image.copyrightHolder: Partner

data.name: Kayaking and chocolate Caslano
data.description: The visit to the chocolate factory near Lugano begins with a special journey. In Agno the visitors are boarding the waiting kayaks and then paddle in the direction of Caslano with their guide. Caslano with Monte Sassalto’s peninsula is a nature preserve well worth visiting.

data.name: Villa Negroni Park
data.abstract: Villa Negroni is one of Ticino’s most important villas. One of the reasons is the valuable expansive garden surrounding the villa. There is a clear division into two contrasting elements: an Italian flower garden and an English-style park.
data.description:
Villa Negroni was built by Lugano’s Carlo Morosini at the turn of the 18th century. The villa, which has been renovated several times, used to be the focus of Ticino society, and various personalities from Italian culture, politicians, intellectuals, musicians and artists were guests here at one time or another.

The flower garden is a rare example of an exclusively Italian garden in Ticino. It was laid out between 1910 and 1920, and impressively demonstrates how architecture and nature can harmoniously blend with one another.

Villa Negroni was most recently renovated by the city of Lugano. The garden also underwent a renovation, in which the original structure was kept and particular attention was drawn to certain key elements. As a result, the whole garden is once again ablaze with the colours of the seasonal flowers that formerly adorned the flower garden.

data.name: Morcote Route
data.description:
The Morcote Route leads through the region south of Lugano, where you get a closer look at the delightful Morcote and Grancia villages that radiate Mediterranean charm. Experience Ceresio and “the sea of cherry trees“, as Lake Lugano is fondly known in the mouths of the Ticino locals; and of course an ice-cream tastes best when eaten under palm trees in Mediterranean-like ambiance. 

Lake Lugano beckons with enjoyable scenic boat trips and there’s naturally no lack of excellent shopping facilities and pretty streets to stroll in the town of Lugano itself. (PostBus stop Lugano, Piazza Rezzonico). Open greens and parks fulfil the promise of relaxation; such as the Parco Civico public park and exotic Belvedere Gardens on the shores of the lake. And Lugano not only represents a business metropolis with own casino, instead also a Mecca for art and culture fans. 

Discover the region’s architectonic masterpieces along with cultural highlights such as the Lugano Estival Jazz event or Blues to Bop. Visual highlights are in store on the Monte San Salvatore (PostBus stop Paradiso, Stazione FFS: Seilbahn), where sweeping views culminate in panoramic views of the lake and surrounding mountains. Superb views are there for the taking also along the Höhenweg Path, which leads through the picturesque Carona artists’ village to Morcote; and lakeside jewel that encourages a dolce-fa-niente lifestyle. (PostBus stop Morcote, Piazza Grande).Visit the Scherrer Park (PostBus stop Morcote, Parco Scherrer) and catch a glimpse of the enchanting arcades and noble abodes. And if you’d like to see more on a smaller scale, (1:25 scale) the open-air Swiss Miniature in Melide is the place to be (PostBusstop Melide, Stazione). 
Additional useful information on the PostBus excursion routes and a wealth of pictures and video clips can be found at the link in the right-hand box.

data.name: San Grato Park
data.abstract: Located between Monte San Salvatore and Monte Arbostora at an altitude of just under 700 metres, the botanical gardens are a mecca for park visitors and plant lovers – particularly in April and May, when the azaleas and rhododendrons form a fragrant carpet.
data.description:
The San Grato botanical gardens are situated above Lake Lugano on the hills of Carona and can be reached by car or bus from Lugano. Covering 62,000m2, the park hosts the largest and most diverse collection of azaleas, rhododendrons and conifers in the whole Insubrian region. 

There are five themed trails through the park: the “Fairytale Trail” is fabulous in the truest sense of the word, giving children a chance to play as they explore the park. Another easy option is the “Relaxation Trail”. The “Botanical Trail” features a large number of information boards about the ornamental plants and wild vegetation in the park. Visitors who follow the “Art Trail” can see works by a selection of artists, while the “Panorama Trail” will take them to the park's various lookout points. This trail is also suitable for a picnic. 
The “Parco botanico di San Grato” is open throughout the year and admission is free.

image.name: sts9095_2.jpg
image.copyrightHolder: Switzerland Tourism/Jan Geerk

data.name: Mendrisio–Monte San Giorgio Route
data.abstract: The Mendrisio–Monte San Giorgio Route leads through the beautiful hilly landscapes of Mendrisiotto before arriving at picturesque and cosy villages of the Monte San Giorgio.
data.description:
Mendrisio, known to most only as a place of transit, is located in the southern-most tip of Switzerland. Get a better view of the spot with its winding little alleyways and lovely old buildings. And the Galleria Baumgartner is sure to delight model railway fans.

Numerous traditional events, such as Easter procession and Palio donkey racing in May, add to the attraction if you’re there at the right time. Another highlight is the vintner festival in September which, in the meanwhile has developed into a grand folk’s event. The journey continues, passing gentle rolling hills and vineyards, to the picturesque Rancate, Besazio, Arzo, Tremona and Meride villages; where, with a short break, you have the time to admire some of the historic architecture and soak-up a little of the typical Ticino charm. 

Meride, with its fossil museum, is yet another name on the list of things and places to see, and a museum that draws people of all ages. (PostBus stop Meride, Posta). Here, visitors witness fossils and imprints up to 230 million years old; excavated from the Monte San Giorgio mountain. The mountain itself offers stupendous views over the Lake Lugano and mountain chain in the backdrop. (PostBus stop Serpiano, Albergo: and one and a half-hour walk to the top). 

And you won’t be surprised to know that the magnificent Monte San Giorgio mountain, from where a number of well preserved fossils have been found, is also a name on the UNESCO World Heritage list. 
Additional useful information on the PostBus excursion routes and a wealth of pictures and video clips can be found at the link in the right-hand box.

data.name: Romantic walk through traditions
data.abstract: Together with a city tour guide, guests can take a leisurely walk to Gandria or mosey through the streets of this picturesque village.
data.description:
The meeting point for the guided tour is the Lugano Region Official Tourism Office. This is where the 75-minute walk to the village of Gandria begins. With its unusual charm, Gandria transports visitors back in time. When wandering through the narrow alleyways, it is easy to envisage how tough everyday life was for the fishermen and their families. After the tour, a boat awaits on the shores of the village for the return to Lugano.

More information [https://www.luganoregion.com/en/attractions-activities/day-trips-surroundings/detail/id/8911/romantic-walk-through-traditions-gandria]

data.name: Golf in Ticino
data.abstract: Ticino means Switzerland paired with Italian flair. And the region’s lakes, mountains and swaying palms, together with Mediterranean-like climate, provide a superb environment for golf.
data.description:
The three Ticino golf clubs (each 18 holes) are distinguished through their elevated technical content and the impeccable care given to their upkeep. Thanks to the mild and sunny climate here, the golfing greens are open year round. GOLF COURSES

18-hole golf courses:

Golf Gerre Losone, Losone [http://www.golflosone.ch/] 
Golf Club Patriziale Ascona, Ascona [http://www.golfascona.ch/] 
Golf Club Lugano, Magliaso [http://www.golflugano.ch/]

data.name: Bernina Express
data.abstract: This panoramic train connects the north of Europe to its south – right through the UNESCO World Heritage site of Rhaetian Railway, passing by glaciers on its way down to palm trees.
data.description:
Crossing the Alps in the Bernina Express certainly is one of the most spectacular ways to do it. Along the way, the Bernina Express rolls over the 65-metre-high Landwasser Viaduct, the signature structure of the Rhaetian Railway and the UNESCO World Heritage site. Altogether the train passes through 55 tunnels and over 196 bridges on its way from Chur to Tirano. Travellers are treated to marvellous sights during their journey, like the Montebello curve with a view of the Bernina massif, the Morteratsch glacier, the three lakes Lej Pitschen, Lej Nair and Lago Bianco, the Alp Grüm and the Brusio Circular Viaduct. The journey can be extended aboard the Bernina Express Bus from Tirano to Lugano from February to November (daily in summer).

FACTS BERNINA EXPRESS (TRAIN)
Route: Chur/St. Moritz – Tirano (Italy) or vice versa Distance: 144 km Duration: 4 h - 4 h 30 min FACTS BERNINA EXPRESS BUS
Route: Tirano (Italy) – Lugano or vice versa Distance: 90 km Duration: 3 h EXCURSION TIPS
 * Arosa Railway – from Chur to Arosa within one hour. On just 26 km, the train negotiates an amazing 1000 m in altitude
 * Railway Museum Albula – over 600 exhibits from more than 100 years of railway history, e.g. one of the last «Crocodile»-Locomotives
 * Gandria – a picturesque little town at the foot of Monte Bré
 * Monte San Salvatore – one of the most beautiful scenic outposts along Lake Lugano
 * Palm Express – rich-in-contrast, roughly four-hour postbus drive from Lugano to St. Moritz
 * Mountain excursion Diavolezza [https://www.myswitzerland.com/en/experiences/diavolezza-1/]

FOOD & BEVERAGES
 * The Bernina Express minibar offers delicious snacks and refreshing beverages
 * The train does not feature a dining car. The guests spend their lunchtime in the Italian town of Tirano

TIMETABLE
 * Summer and winter timetable panoramic trains [https://tickets.rhb.ch/en/pages/bernina-express]
 * Timetable regular scheduled service [http://www.sbb.ch/en/home.html]

TICKET
This route is fully covered by the Swiss Travel Pass (Flex) and GA travelcard.
Book public transport tickets [https://www.myswitzerland.com/en/planning/transport-accommodation/tickets-public-transport/]

RESERVATION
Apart from a valid ticket, a seat reservation is required on both train and bus. In addition, a reservation surcharge applies:

RESERVATION SURCHARGE BERNINA EXPRESS (TRAIN)

data.name: Monte San Giorgio
data.abstract: Its summit offers up magnificent views and those inclined to scratch about on it will be left with the impression that marine fauna and other large animals once lived here.
data.description:
The Monte San Giorgio is the Swiss saurian mountain; it has gained in prominence as a transnational locality since 2010 when the UNESCO extension also took in the Italian side of the mountain. 

This mountain has a truly rich inner life: rising just under 1100 metres in height, the Monte San Giorgio in the sunny south of Ticino has been a Mecca for fossil scientists since the 19th century, and a Unesco World Heritage site since 2003. Thousands of fossilised fish and marine saurians of up to six metres in length have already been unearthed here by eager palaeontologists. And for good reason: 230 to 245 million years ago, this was the site of a 100-metre-deep ocean basin. Today, at the southern end of Lake Lugano, the Monte San Giorgio rises like a pyramid – inside, filled with all manner of fossils. One can stroll through the vineyards along the southern slopes of the woody mountain, saunter through the idyllic town of Meride, or allow oneself to be pampered in the grottos of the Mendrisiotto region. 

Around 80 different species of fish and 30 marine and land reptiles have been discovered at the numerous excavation sites. What’s more, the scientists have also found hundreds of fossilised invertebrate animals and plants from the middle Triassic period, 230 to 245 million years ago. 

Remodeled and expanded by the Ticinese architect Mario Botta, the Fossil Museum in Meride exhibits a selection of fossilized animals and plants from the unique UNESCO World Heritage Site of Monte San Giorgio.

data.name: Everyone loves chocolate
data.abstract: “Nine out of ten people like chocolate. The tenth is lying.” (Graffiti scrawled on a wall ). Every Swiss child would agree: their favourite afternoon snack has always been bread and chocolate. During the more than 400 years since Columbus became the first European to see cocoa beans, Switzerland has come to the forefront of chocolate manufacturing worldwide. Swiss chocolatiers have created such delights as truffles, pralines, cakes, and mousses (enough to make a Swiss child forget about the bread ) … Swiss chocolate is great on its own, or with an espresso, a sweet wine, whisky or a Cognac, and on any conceivable occasion. For more on the subject, see: www.chocosuisse.ch
data.description:
THE SWISS CHOCOLATE TRAIN
Travel first-class in a genuine 19th century Belle Époque Pullman car from Montreux through an idyllic landscape, and visit a cheese dairy, a castle, and the Cailler-Nestlé factory in Broc, all on the Swiss Chocolate Train, operated by Golden- Pass Services. Runs June to October. More Information... [http://www.myswitzerland.com/en/reisen/transport/bahnreisen-zugfahren-panoramastrecken/swiss-chocolate-train.html] 

CHOCOLATE HEAVEN
There’s no need for false modesty: Swiss chocolatiers are the best in the world. Every town and city in Switzerland has its favourite practitioner of the art, Teuscher [http://www.teuscher.com] on Bahnhofstrasse in Zürich, for example, for champagne truffles, or Blondel [https://blondel.ch/fr/] in Lausanne’s Old Town, with 120 different creations. 

BEHIND THE SCENES
Chocosuisse is an association of 18 different chocolate makers, large and small, some of which are open to visits by the public. Visitors can learn how chocolate is produced from an audiovisual presentation, follow a tour, have a tasting, and buy chocolate to take away from the factory shop. Chocolate makers include:

 * Cailler-Nestlé [https://www.cailler.ch/en/maison-cailler] in Broc/FR (open April-October)
 * Alprose [http://www.alprose.ch] in Caslano-Lugano/TI (daily)
 * Maestrani [https://www.chocolarium.ch/fr/] in Flawil/SG (Monday- Saturday)
 * Aeschbach Chocolatier [https://aeschbach-chocolatier.ch/en/choco-events/] in Root/LU (open Monday - Sunday, online registration possible)
 * Chocolat Frey [https://www.chocolatfrey.ch/centre-visiteurs/page-d-accueil] in Buchs/AG (groups, by appointment only)
 * Läderach [http://www.schoggi-erlebnis.ch/en/] in Bilten, Ennenda, Vevey and Zurich.


Swiss Chocolate Adventure 
The Swiss Chocolate Adventure is a new theme world within the Swiss Muesum of Transport that allows the visitor to learn interesting facts about the discovery, origin, production and transport of chocolate. 
Mehr Informationen hier [https://www.verkehrshaus.ch/fr/visiter/swiss-chocolate-adventure.html]

data.name: The fabulous fifties
data.description: Hosts Conny and Markus Wilke share a passion for the good, old days. Their guests are immersed in the 1950s and get to feel like film stars Marylin Monroe and James Dean driving around Lake Lugano in an original Ford Thunderbird convertible. For dinner, a hamburger is served, just like a date in a diner. And, as a souvenir of the special outing into the 50s, everyone gets a photo with the convertible to take home.

data.name: Erlebniszug San Gottardo
data.description: From May to October, every second Saturday of the month, the “Erlebniszug San Gottardo” makes the trip along the Gotthard railway line from Erstfeld to Bodio and back. A Ce 6/8 II “Crocodile” or the legendary Ae 6/6 serves as a locomotive for the historic train journey. The guests travel the way they would have done in days gone by. Along the way, there are connections to numerous excursion destinations, such as Andermatt, Bellinzona, Locarno or Lugano. The “Erlebniszug San Gottardo” makes its way south from Erstfeld around 9:45 a.m. The locomotive change manoeuvre takes place in Bodio around midday. With stops in Faido, Airolo and Göschenen, the train travels along the Gotthard railway line with its seven impressive loop tunnels back to Erstfeld, where the train arrives around 4:25 p.m.

data.name: The Madonna degli Angioli church
data.abstract: The church, which was originally part of a Franciscan monastery, is home to Switzerland's most famous Renaissance fresco. It covers the whole wall of the nave. The "Passion and and Crucifixion of Christ" is defined by great expressiveness and vividness of the individual scenes.
data.description:
The whole fresco resembles a magnificent gobelin. Take some time to study it closely. On the left wall of the nave is a large fresco depicting the Last Supper and on the first of the four side altars is also a fresco, depicting the Virgin Mary and the Christ Child. Both are attributed to Luini and reflect the influence of Leonardo da Vinci.

The church is located on Piazza Bernardino Luini, at the end of Via Nassa, the city's elegant shopping boulevard.

data.name: Piz Nair
data.abstract: A stately ibex, head bowed, sits atop its throne on the summit of Piz Nair, overlooking the Upper Engadin at its feet.
data.description:
The Chantarella-Corviglia funicular railway takes you from the centre of St. Moritz up to the top of the resort’s local mountain. The Signal cable car from St. Moritz Bad also takes you in the direction of Corviglia. Another cable car then takes summiteers even closer to heaven and the Piz Nair upper station at exactly 3,056 metres above sea level. Without breaking a sweat or exerting yourself, you can enjoy an unforgettable view of St. Moritz, the Upper Engadin lake region and the mountains.

The summit falls away steeply on all sides, but with a sturdy pair of boots you can tackle the descent via the picturesque Lej Suvretta or into Valetta Schlattain. Mountain bikers love the descent of Alp Suvretta back to St. Moritz, with an altitude difference of 1,200 metres.

The “Clean Energy Tour [http://www.clean-energy.ch/fileadmin/user_upload_cleanenergy/user_upload/pdf/Clean_Energy_Tour_Flyer.pdf]” between Piz Nair and St. Moritz provides an extensive presentation of the “Energy from Water, Sun, Wind and Biomass” project.

Altitude: 3,022 metres 
How to get there: Train from Chur to St. Moritz, funicular railways to Chantarella/Corviglia, cable car to Piz Nair 
Views: Towards Muottas Muragl, the Piz Palü and Bernina region, Corvatsch, the Bregaglia Alps, Italy’s Monte Disgrazia in the distance; to the west and north lie Piz Julier, Piz Ela and Piz Kesch 
Attractions: View from the second-highest mountain in the Upper Engadin accessible by cable car; long bike descents 
Food and drink: Panorama restaurant on Piz Nair, restaurants in Corviglia and Lej da la Pêsch 
Accommodation: None on the summit 
Groups: In the panorama restaurant by arrangement 
Winter: Winter sports area of St. Moritz / Upper Engadin 
Special comments: The 60-year-old bronze ibex, “Guardiaun Grischun” is the symbol of Piz Nair.

data.name: Glacier Palace in the Matterhorn Glacier Paradise
data.abstract: High, higher - the Glacier Palace in the Matterhorn Glacier Paradise. Even the mountain train ride tops all records.
data.description:
At 3820 m, you step out into a world of snow, ice and mountain peaks. To the west you see the Matterhorn [https://www.myswitzerland.com/en/destinations/matterhorn-4478-m-asl-landmark-of-switzerland/], the most famous mountain in Switzerland, and in the East is the Breithorn with the majestic Monte Rosa behind it. On the broad glacier between the Klein Matterhorn and the Breithorn is the highest Glacier Palace in the world, offering fantastic views of the fascinating world of snow and ice.

A lift travels 15 m into a glacier where glittering ice crystals and ice sculptures generate a world of their own. They are periodically replaced by new creations from different artists. An ice tunnel continues through the glacier to an ice chute or into a crevasse. Soft and fluffy seats are provided on ice benches to make the icy adventure cosy and comfortable. 

Directions:
By car from Sierre [https://www.myswitzerland.com/en/destinations/sierre/]via Visp [https://www.myswitzerland.com/en/destinations/visp/]to Täsch [https://www.myswitzerland.com/en/destinations/taesch/], from Täsch by train to Zermatt [https://www.myswitzerland.com/en/destinations/zermatt/]and by mountain transportation [https://www.myswitzerland.com/en/experiences/matterhorn-glacier-ride/]to the Matterhorn glacier paradise, by public transportation from Sierre via Visp to Zermatt, mountain transportation.

data.name: Monte Verità
data.abstract: Just a 15-minute walk from Ascona rises the 321 metre tall Monte Verità. The panoramic view of the village and the Lago Maggiore is fantastic – just like the story of the eccentrics from around the world who established an early hippy colony here in 1900. This spirit can still be seen today in the hotel, in the museum – and while strolling through the park.
data.description:
At the beginning of the 20th century, an open spirit prevailed on the Monescia, as Monte Verità above Ascona was originally called: a group of eccentrics from around the world had settled down here in order to devote themselves to free love, vegetarianism, nudism and psychoanalysis. After twenty years, the experiment failed because the requirements of those involved were too different. 

Almost thirty years later, the rich German Baron Eduard von der Heydt has a Bauhaus hotel built on the hill, which was renovated and extended in 1992. Today, Monte Verità presents itself as an attractive conference centre and as a health resort with a wonderful park, open to visitors all year round, with a broad perspective, illustrious past, a good restaurant and an interesting museum.

data.name: Breggia Gorges
data.abstract: A trip to the Breggia Gorges is a real time travelling experience. In this part of the Mendrisiotto along the Breggia River you will find some unusual geological formations.
data.description:
It is exactly these geological structures that make Breggia Gorges Park in the Muggio Valley the best geopark in the country. About 80 million years ago, between the Jurassic and Tertiary Periods, water began eroding the rocks, creating the formations we see today. The stones hold the evidence of these ancient seas: fossils, the remains of underwater avalanches and signs of climate change that all occurred before humans ever existed. These finds make it possible to reconstruct the evolution of Monte Generoso’s basin in the very distant past.

The Park is alive with plants and animals, many of which are endangered or protected species. This region also boasts historically and culturally interesting buildings such as the Rote Kirche Church from the 14th century and the 12th century castle of Castel San Pietro. The historic streets are also worth exploring. The Park has two paths: one offering a geological tour and the other a historical tour.

Getting there: The Park can be reached both by public transport (Balerna train station) and car. There is an information point and car park at the Ghitello Mill.

data.name: Augustinian Monte Carasso Monastery
data.abstract: The foundation of the monastery and its associated church dates back to the year 1450. However, the mid-19th century saw the monastery closed and left to decay. It was only in the eighties of the 20th century that the monastery was shaken awake through a total renovation – and brought back to life at the village center under the supervision of the eminent Swiss architect Luigi Snozzi.
data.description:
Instead of the original idea of decentralization, Snozzi’s project viewed added value to the historic village core. The former monastery therefore developed into a modern community center for diverse public and religious institutions - and a pioneering example of planning in public space. In 1993 the project was thus awarded the Wakker Prize, along with further recognition through the «1993 Prince of Wales» award. Today, individual rooms of the monastery can be rented for seminars. 

Also worth a visit: the church of San Bernardo, higher above, with remarkable frescoes from the 15th to 17th centuries. The key to the church is obtainable from valley station of the cable car station to Mornera.

data.name: Photo Spot Cardada
data.abstract: The cable car, originally built in 1952 and redesigned by architect Mario Botta in 2000, takes you to Cardada in only 5 minutes. The unique and unsurpassed panorama covers the entire Locarno region, while at the same time allowing you to see both Switzerland’s lowest point (Lake Maggiore) as well as its highest point (Dufourspitze, the highest peak of Monte Rosa)! The two-seater chairlift from Cardada to Cimetta runs parallel to the railway axis and provides you with an unrivalled, breathtaking view.

data.name: Anaïs in Ascona-Locarno
data.abstract: The region of Ascona-Locarno has a lot to offer for the entire family. From llama trekking to exciting treasure hunts, there’s plenty to do. Anaïs and her family enjoyed an exciting short break in Switzerland’s sunniest region.
data.description:
Hello Family [https://www.hellofamily.ch/de.html] blogger Anaïs and her family put the family destination Ascona-Locarno to the test from 3 to 7 June 2019. They stayed at Albergo Losone [https://www.myswitzerland.com/en/accommodations/albergo-losone/], a Swiss Family Hotel & Lodging.



The family tells us about their experience in Ascona-Locarno:

“We really liked Ascona-Locarno because it offers an array of activities. For our daughter, the falconry centre in Locarno and the playground on the Monte Cardada with the treasure hunt were the highlights. The llama trekking [https://www.myswitzerland.com/en/experiences/llama-trekking-on-monte-comino/]on the Monte Comino and the Brissago Islands, with their botanical garden, were also amazing. Our hotel in Losone was fantastic. The children’s room and the heated swimming pool were perfect for our daughter.”

data.name: Sunnegga - Rothorn
data.abstract: Some people say that the Matterhorn is best viewed from the Rothorn, since it showcases its pyramid shape perfectly. And who are we to argue? The mountains to the east of Zermatt are great viewpoints.
data.description:
The journey into the mountains begins with the underground funicular railway to Sunnegga (2,288 metres above sea level). This was the first funicular in Switzerland to travel entirely inside a tunnel. At Sunnegga you can watch marmots at play, while the nearby Leisee lake is the perfect spot for a swim.

 The journey then continues by eight-person gondola to Blauherd (2,571 metres above sea level). From here, the themed Marmot Trail leads back to Sunnegga and the five-lake trail into the valley of the Findel Glacier.

Finally, a big cable car takes visitors to the summit of the Unterrothorn (3,103 metres above sea level). The views of most of the 38 four-thousand-metre peaks around Zermatt are quite simply breathtaking.



Altitude: 3,103 metres 
How to get there: Train from Brig/Visp to Zermatt, on foot or by free e-bus (green line) to the valley station Sunnegga-Rothorn: funicular to Sunnegga [https://www.matterhornparadise.ch/en/experience/peaks/sunnegga], gondola to Blauherd [https://www.matterhornparadise.ch/en/experience/peaks/blauherd], cable car to the Rothorn [https://www.matterhornparadise.ch/en/experience/peaks/rothorn]
Views: Across Zermatt to the Obergabelhorn, Zinalrothorn and Weisshorn, with the Bernese Alps in the background, over the Findel Glacier to the Rimpfischhorn and Strahlhorn, over the Gornergrat ridge to Monte Rosa and of course the Matterhorn itself 
Attractions: Starting point to numerous themed hiking trails (e.g. Five Lakes Walk, Path to Freedom, Flower Trail), Moonlight descent in winter, Sunrise rides, Leisee lake with children’s playground
Food and drink: Mountain restaurants at all levels, sun terraces with magnificent mountain views, Rothorn cablecar: Sunrise rides including Älpler breakfast every Tuesday during summer
Accommodation: No accommodation at Sunnegga, Blauherd or Rothorn; Fluhalp has single, double, triple, quadruple and group rooms, Mountain Lodge Ze Seewjinu has double, triple, quadruple and group rooms
Groups: Rothorn has two rooms with seating for 76 in each; Blauherd Blue Lounge; Sunegga has rooms with seating for 192, 140 and 100, conferences for up to 200, meeting rooms 
Winter: Rothorn Paradise winter sports area, linked to the Gornergrat and Matterhorn Paradise 
Special comments: Probably the most photogenic angle for Matterhorn views!

Book your tickets [https://www.matterhornparadise.ch/en/book/tickets/rothorn]

data.name: Gemmipass
data.abstract: Already the Romans trod this path from the main Valais valley to the north. The historic Gemmipass crossing unites Leukerbad with Kandersteg – without roads, instead mountain rail.
data.description:
These were followed by soldiers, pilgrims and traders - and many famous people such as Mark Twain, Lenin and Pablo Picasso, also got to know this wild and rugged region. Where wealthy travellers once travelled, followed by the famous "Gemmi-Wägeli" carriages, today the modern Gemmibahn railway takes passengers over the cantonal border on the steep 900 meter climb from Leukerbad.

The "Berghotel Wildstrubel" awaits guests at the top, along with two diverse via ferrata and a viewing platform at dizzying height. 
Altitude: 2346m 
Accessibility: 
Train to Leuk, bus to Leukerbad, cable car to the Gemmi Pass.
From Kandersteg with the local bus to the valley station, cable car to the Sunnbüel, 2-hour and15 minutes hike to the Gemmipass 
View: Down to Leukerbad and through the Lonza Valley, over the Rhone Valley to the Mischabel, Monte Rosa, Weisshorn, Matterhorn and Dent Blanche mountains; as well as Wildstrubel’s Lämmerenboden 
Attractions: Breathtaking viewing platform, adventurous Gemmi-wall via ferrata, hike to the Daubensee lake and over the Gemmi plane to Sunnebüel (to Kandersteg) 
Culinary aspects: Rösti, toasted cheese slice, pan-fried dishes, Fondue 
Overnight stays: Double and multi-bedrooms, dormitory 
Groups: Panorama restaurant 160 places, plus sun terrace with views of the Valais high Alps
Rooms for seminars and meetings 
Winter: Facilities and mountain hotel open,16 kilometers of cross-country skiing tracks, snowshoe trails and winter hikes (by favourable conditions as far as Sunnebüel) 
Special comments: Purest relaxation after a mountain hike at the Leukerbad thermal baths.

data.name: Lac de Joux
data.abstract: The Lac de Joux lies in a high valley of the same name. It is remarkable in that no surface flows out of it. There is a motorboat service in summer from Le Pont to the other end of the lake.
data.description: Lac de Joux and the nearly adjacent but much smaller Lac Brenet have no surface drainage: the water trickles away underground and only comes to the surface again a few kilometres away near Vallorbe. In July and August there is just one scheduled boat service every day on the Lac de Joux, doing a round trip in the afternoons, starting at Le Pont at the north-eastern end of the lake. In June and September, the boat only runs on Saturdays and Sundays. This makes the Lac de Joux shipping company one of the smallest in Switzerland, and a ride on the lake something really special.

data.name: Lac de Taney: Mountain Lake on the Haute-Savoie Border
data.abstract: This beautiful dark blue lake is surrounded by flower-strewn fields, tall, fragrant fir trees and rocks.
data.description:
The many flowers here include the alpine rose, monk's hood and mountain violet among others. Frogs croak on the shore and the shady forests nearby attract alpine salamanders. This is not surprising, since the Lac de Taney is well-known for attracting a vast number of amphibians.
This miniature paradise is located at an altitude of 1,500 m and overlooks the Rhone valley. It was declared a national natural heritage site in the Sixties, but thanks to the visionaries of the time, the lake was not exposed to mass tourism as originally planned. It can still be visited, however, and you can even stay in the charming little mountain inn on the Western shore of the lake.
The road leading to Lac de Taney is closed to private vehicles. Hike from Le Flon, the end station of the Swiss Post Bus line.

How to get there:
By car: drive from Montreux via Vouvry / Miex towards Lac de Taney, or use public transport to reach Miex (final hiking trail).

data.name: Perle du Lac Park and Botanical Garden
data.abstract: With its magical view of Mont-Blanc across the lake, Perle du Lac Park is the ideal place for relaxing moments spent by the lakeside. It’s no wonder that the wife of Rolex founder Hans Wilsdorf called this place the “pearl of the lake”.
data.description:
From Perle du Lac Park, it’s not far to the botanical garden by the lake shore. There, you’ll also find the little harbour with the jetty for the “mouettes genevoises” (ferries) linking the two sides of the lake. The park is an extension of Mon Repos and Moynier Park, with a marvellous view of the lake.

On the grounds of Geneva’s botanical gardens, spread over 28 hectares and showcasing more than 12,000 kinds of plants and trees, you’ll find the kind of peace and quiet that invites you to meditate and reflect. The 21-metre-high neoclassical greenhouse reminiscent of a miniature palace is particularly striking. This is home to plants requiring Mediterranean climate conditions from all over the world, such as succulents or gigantic palms, whose leaves reach all the way to the dome. With its six million samples, the garden’s herbarium is one of the largest in the world.

data.name: Estavayer-le-Lac - Beach and Watersports
data.abstract: Estavayer-le-Lac is a medieval town situated beside Lake Neuchâtel and is home to the best-equipped watersports centre in Switzerland.The highlight is a ride on the 800-metre long water skiing lift - Switzerland’s longest.
data.description:
The "Nouvelle Plage" ("New Beach") has a games area, restaurant and camping site and welcomes families with open arms. Pedal-boats, windsurfing boards and catamarans are available for hire. The unique waterski-lift is a must for the entire family and is suitable for children who can swim (recommended age: 10).

INFORMATION

HOW TO GET THERE
By car: use the A1/E25 motorway route.
By train: Take the Fribourg-Yverdon line.

data.name: Stand-Up Paddling Champex-Lac
data.abstract: In the summer, paddle boards provide visitors with the possibility of gliding over the clear waters of Lake Champex in a fairy tale setting.
data.description:
The town of Champex is a little bit of Canada in Switzerland, with its dense forests, traditional wood chalets and magnificent lake. A little hut on the water’s edge offers boards for hire in hot weather so you can make the most of the relaxing scenery in the heart of the mountains.



For more information [https://www.champex.ch/fr/activites/faites-le-plein-d-activites/annuaire-des-activites/item/6134-pedalos-et-stand-up-paddle]

data.name: Winter delight on the Lac de Joux
data.abstract: Walking or skating on the largest frozen lake in the Jura mountain range is an experience not to be missed.
data.description:
When Nature is clad in its white winter garb, here, far from the hurly-burly of larger ski resorts, you will have plenty of fun skating in a family environment. In the cold winter months, the frozen lake turns into a fantastic playground for all skaters and sail cart fans. On several occasions during the season, there may be thousands of visitors enjoying skating in complete safety on the frozen Lac de Joux.

More information [https://www.myvalleedejoux.ch/en/P22607/frozen-lakes-in-the-vallee-de-joux]

data.name: Watersports on Lake Gruyère
data.abstract: Lake Gruyère (Lac de la Gruyère) is the longest and second-largest artificial lake in Switzerland, measuring 13.5 kilometres and covering almost ten square kilometres at high water. This is precisely why the lake on the edge of the Fribourg foothills is so popular for all kinds of watersports.
data.description:
The elongated lake between Fribourg and Bulle stretches from Broc to Rossens, following the former course of the River Saane. Rossens is the location of the dam built in 1947. On the small island known as “Vers les Tours” in the middle of the lake stands a castle ruin with a chapel – often the setting for fairytale weddings. The small town of Pont-en-Ogoz stood here until the mid-15th century, surrounded by the Saane. When the river was dammed many ruins sank into the lake, leaving behind the idyllic surroundings on the island. 

A private organisation offers boat trips in summer with information about the lake and the important historic settlement of Ogoz. Rowing boats, kayaks and canoes can all be seen on Lake Gruyère – in recent years they have been joined by many stand-up paddle boarders. Various companies offer canoe hire and/or guided tours.

data.name: Fondation Pierre Arnaud
data.abstract: Alone the facade of this museum is extraordinary: 84 solar panels of glass cover the building of Architect Jean-Pierre Emery - with the surroundings, Lac de Louché and the Valais mountains mirrored therein. Inside visitors meet with an exhibition space of around 1000 square meters, upon which the unusual and changing exhibits never cease to positively surprise viewers.
data.description:
Opened in 2013, the Fondation Pierre Arnaud aims to create a kind of dialogue between Swiss and European art. And the approximately 1000-square-meter exhibition space on two floors lures visitors with three new shows a year. The summer and winter exhibitions surprise with themes such as "Homme Noir - Blanc Homme" or "Der Teufel, die Feder und der Pinsel“ (the devil, feather and paint brush). Major Swiss collections are exhibited in autumn. 


And it’s not only the exhibits worth looking at, instead the building itself that certainly merits a second glance: The roof of this strictly rectangular building, the conceptual makings of which are attributed to the local architect Jean-Pierre Emery, is decked out with 84 solar panels of glass. The shimmering facade thus reflects the pretty Lac de Louche and Valais summits - as the building merges with the landscape in which it lies.

data.name: Ice diving
data.abstract: A magical spectacle waits to be seen under the white surface of frozen Lac Lioson.
data.description: "Located above Les Mosses, Lac Lioson is a pearl among the lakes of the Alps. Covered with ice and snow in the winter, it appears to be sleeping, but a natural spectacle is unfolding underneath its blanket of ice. Accompanied and instructed by experienced divers, guests can dive underneath the ice. The water is clear, allowing divers to observe a magical light play in this enchanted, icy world, guided by an Ariadne’s thread. There are bubbles formed by the ice, and you will even see a few fish swimming in the lake under the ice.

data.name: Saut du Doubs
data.abstract: The water of the river Doubs, which has been dammed up by landslide debris, forms the four kilometer long, but only 200 meter wide, winding Lac des Brenets. The 27 meter high Doubs Falls are located at its end. The Falls can be reached on foot or by passenger boat.
data.description:
The little river of Doubs was dammed up by a landslide 14,000 years ago. Since then the waters have partially eroded their way through the debris and boulders. The banks of Lac des Brenets are at first flat, but towards the end of the lake they turn into steep banks of white limestone rocks, up to 80 meters high.

Lac des Brenets is long and winding, like a serpent, and is, thanks to its natural beauty, a popular destination for excursions. It is often used for bathing in the summer or for boat rides. Cruise ships travel regularly between the town of Les Brenets and the Saut du Doubs Falls. The 27 meter high waterfall can also be reached by means of a one-hour hike from Les Brenets. 

The waterfall forms the border between Switzerland and France, with footpaths on both sides to help visitors find the best spot for a photo; a bridge can only be found at the end of the Lac des Brenets.

data.name: Chenaux Castle
data.abstract: In the heart of the small medieval town of Estavayer-le-Lac stands the Château de Chenaux, overlooking Lake Neuchâtel and the reed beds of the Grande Cariçaie nature reserve.
data.description:
Without a doubt, the most important building in Estavayer-le-Lac is the Château de Chenaux. It is located in the old town above a steep slope and transports visitors back to mediaeval times. The Savoyard castle dates back to the 13th century.

Humbert the Bastard bought the castle in 1432 and transformed it into a fortress. After his death, the castle was acquired by Jacques d’Estavayer, who also took over as ruler. In 1475, after Estavayer had been taken by the forces of the Swiss Confederation, Fribourg occupied the castle, which it still owns to this day.

The rectangular complex has a 33-metre-high keep, the walls of which are three metres thick. The castle has undergone several renovations and expansions. Only one of the original three towers has survived: this now serves as a dovecote.

data.name: ArtiChoke urban art route
data.abstract: A unique route awaits visitors in the heart of the medieval town of Estavayer-le-Lac: the urban art route includes 15 works by artists from a wide variety of disciplines, that are consistently based on modern and contemporary art.
data.description:
Strolling between historic facades and Lake Neuchâtel while discovering original artworks becomes a reality on the ArtiChoke route in Estavayer-le-Lac [https://www.myswitzerland.com/en/destinations/estavayer-le-lac/]. The highly accessible open-air gallery offers a thematic tour that is in stark contrast to the medieval town. Please allow a little more than an hour for your visit. The tour is self-guided using a map that can be downloaded or collected at no charge from the town’s tourist office. And if you would like to find out more about the artists, you can also book a guided tour.

The route brings together some fifteen works [https://www.fribourgregion.ch/wp-content/uploads/2021/11/estavayer-262900-brochuere-artichoke.pdf] that have been painted, modelled, shaped or produced using other techniques at various sites around the historic town. Swiss and international artists bring to life diverse and sometimes offbeat worlds.

One of the facades along the Grand-Rue has been decorated by Spanish artist Raquel Rodrigo, using an embroidery technique that is popular worldwide. You can also discover an impressive work made up of 788 origami works by French artist Mademoiselle Maurice. These urban artists have taken over a wall in Switzerland for the first time, where they will be presenting works created specifically for the tour.

The ArtiChoke Festival [https://www.artichokefestival.ch]is held in Estavayer-le-Lac every two years, in the summer. Art lovers and curious newcomers will not come away from the event disappointed. The programme includes live painting, musical animations, audiovisual performances, temporary exhibitions and culinary offerings with various food trucks.

More information [https://www.fribourgregion.ch/en/estavayer-payerne/visits/artichoke-itinerary-of-urban-art/] about the tour.

What is the meaning behind the name “ArtiChoke”? The word comes from a combination of the words “art” and “choc”, the French word for “shock”. It alludes to the clash of medieval walls with contemporary urban art. A name that stands out and surprises.
