data.name: Vevey lake promenade
data.abstract: The lakeside promenade in Vevey on Lake Geneva combines beautiful nature with culture. Stroll along flowering gardens, marvel at the famous fork sculpture in the water and visit the Charlie Chaplin statue.
data.description:
The lakeside promenade in Vevey is one of the most beautiful lakeside promenades on Lake Geneva (Lac Léman) and offers fantastic views of the lake and the Alps.

Along the promenade you will find flowering gardens and numerous works of art. A particular highlight is the iconic fork sculpture that rises out of the water and stands directly in front of the Alimentarium. This lakeside promenade is perfect for relaxing strolls while enjoying the picturesque landscape around Vevey.

Another popular photo motif is the Charlie Chaplin statue, which also stands on the lakeside promenade and commemorates the world-famous actor who lived in the region for many years. The combination of nature, art and history makes Vevey's lakeside promenade an ideal destination for tourists and locals alike.

data.name: Snowtubing
data.abstract: Flying down the slope on a snowtube is lots of fun for all ages.
data.description:
The area around Lac de Tracouet is a perfect place for families. Here, parents and their children can grab a snowtube and get the drag-lift to the start. From there, you can speed off downhill. If you need a little rest after all the snowtubing, you can sit back on a lounger while the children have fun in the play area.

Use of the snowtubes and facilities at Lac de Tracouet is included in the lift pass.


More information [https://www.nendaz.ch/en/fppoi-snowtubing-tracouet-lake-35917-14754.html]

data.name: Old City of Vevey
data.abstract: The old city of Vevey is dotted with historical monuments and museums bearing witness to its rich heritage. In addition, a large variety of boutiques and craftsmen can be found in the narrow paved streets, displaying their know-how and wares.
data.description:
The pedestrian zone of the old city, the lakeside, and the market (Tuesday and Saturday mornings) in the Grande Place (the heart of the old city), are well worth a browse. 

From the Place de la Gare, walk towards the lake to the Grande Place and the Vevey landing stage. Each Tuesday and Saturday morning in summer, the square belongs to the famous Vevey market, with its colourful, perfumed stands offering flowers, fruits, vegetables, cheeses, meats, fish and old objects. On Saturdays in July and August, these markets give way to folklore markets: thanks to a glass of wine - you pay for your first glass only - everyone can sample the various regional wine appellations in the company of their vintners! The atmosphere is assured with fanfares, alphorns and winegrowers in their traditional costumes! 

Via the Rue du Lac (on the east side of the Grande Place, after the Swiss Camera Museum), you come to the picturesque part of Vevey, intimate and pedestrians only.

data.name: The Architectural Work of Le Corbusier
data.abstract: Few architects have left such a mark on modern building worldwide as Charles-Edouard Jeanneret - better known as Le Corbusier - who grew up in La Chaux-de-Fonds. 17 selected works in seven countries have been designated UNESCO World Heritage Sites.
data.description:
In addition to the two buildings in Switzerland, the 17 selected objects are located in Argentina, Belgium, Germany, France, India and Japan. They are evidence of Le Corbusier‘s unparalleled creativity and versatility in various contexts. 

The two awarded buildings in Switzerland are: 

Villa Le Lac Le Corbusier [http://https://www.villalelac.ch/en], Corseaux [http://https://www.villalelac.ch/en]

 L'Immeuble Clarté, Geneva [https://www.sites-le-corbusier.org/oeuvres/immeuble-clarte-geneve%EF%BF%BC%EF%BF%BC/]

 [https://www.geneve.com/en/attractions/le-corbusier-building%C2%A0-la-clarte/]
Le Corbusier is considered one of the most influential architects, designers and design theoreticians of the 20th century. Born Charles-Edouard Jeanneret in 1887 in La Chaux-de-Fonds, he studied architecture and moved to Paris, where he met, among others, industrial designer Peter Behrens. His concept of the house as a «machine for living» included functional furniture or «équipement de l’habitation». 

Le Corbusier is seen as a key figure of the internationalization of architecture and urban planning, which has characterized the urban landscapes of the 20th century.

data.name: Vineyard walks in the canton of Vaud
data.abstract: The traditional art of viticulture meets modern technology: using your smartphone and the free Vaude:Guide app, you can experience the region’s winegrowing areas in an interactive way.
data.description:
The viticultural trails of the Vaud region document the art and history of wine cultivation in the area. The fascinating information boards are supplemented with anecdotes and games on the Vaud:Guide app. To find out how the app works, click on this link [https://www.region-du-leman.ch/en/Z7628/vineyard-walks-in-the-canton-of-vaud]. The quiz questions and games are suitable for children from the age of eight, ensuring plenty of fun for all the family on the discovery trail. While the virtual companion is of course excellent, no visit would be complete without sampling some local drops in the real surroundings of a wine cellar. 




A walk through the UNESCO-listed Lavaux vineyard terraces
The 10km hike takes a good four-and-a-half hours to complete, with plenty of chances to taste the superb local wines at venues along the way over the slopes above Lake Geneva.

A walk in Pays-d’Enhaut
Hikers can enjoy wine and top-class cheese on this nine-kilometre route. This two-and-a-half hour walk is a chance to admire no less than 30 tourist highlights.

A walk in Vallée de Joux
Completing the full 25km circuit around Lac de Joux takes about six hours. The route can be halved for a more manageable hike: walk from Le Pont to Sentier or vice versa, following the right or left shore of the lake.

A walk through the vineyards of Vully
This 11km walk though Switzerland’s smallest wine growing area lasts about three hours and affords amazing views of Lake Murten.

A walk through the vineyards of Morges
This interesting hike through the region’s vineyards is six kilometres in length and takes three-and-a-half hours, passing through the picturesque town of Morges along the way. 

A walk through the vineyards of Bonvillars
This 11km hike of around four hours is perfectly rounded off by taking the PostBus to the little market town of Grandson.

A walk through the vineyards of Côtes de l’Orbe – panorama

With a total ascent of almost 300m over its 13km length, this pleasant hike will lead you up and down the slopes of the region’s vineyards over three-and-a-half hours.

A walk through the vineyards of Côtes de l’Orbe – the foothills of the Jura
This 14km hike through the foothills of the Jura is at times a little challenging and takes four-and-half hours to complete.

A walk through the vineyards of Chablais
It takes around four hours to walk the nine kilometres of this leisurely trail on the slopes of the Chablais region.

A walk through the vineyards of Luins-Begnins
Castles, panorama views and plenty of vineyards await on this five-kilometre, two-and-a-half hour route.

A walk through the vineyards of Vinzel-Bursins
This walk is also five kilometres long and takes two-and-a-half hours.

A walk through the Morges winery
It takes just 30 minutes to walk this one-kilometre trail through the wine-growing estate in the town of Morges.

data.name: St. Bernard Express
data.abstract: Starting point for the St. Bernard Express is in Martigny in the canton of Valais.
data.description:
Route: Martigny - Orsières - Grand St-Bernard

Just like the Mont-Blanc Express, the St. Bernard Express also has its point of origin in Martigny. Pass through the Val d'Entremont to Orsières, from where a bus will take you to Champex-Lac, La Fouly or if it is summer (June to end of September) to the hospice on the Grand St. Bernard Pass. There visit the legendary kennels where the dogs of the same name are bred, as well as the small local museum to view the Roman artifacts found here.

data.name: By kayak to a fondue party
data.description: The guests have to be a bit athletic to earn their fondue in the old ruin of “Château d’Ogoz”. After an introduction to the use of a kayak they paddle across magical lake «Lac de La Gruyère» with a guide from La Roche. On the Isle of Ogoz they have the opportunity to take a walk and explore the ruins.

data.name: Geneva Wine Trail
data.abstract: The longest vineyard walk in Switzerland. Discover the magnificent Geneva countryside by following three fascinating didactic itineraries combining wine growing, nature and local products.
data.description:
The vineyard walk criss-crosses Geneva, Switzerland’s third-largest wine producer. The three itineraries are equipped with information panels introducing Geneva’s grape varieties. The Rive Droite (right bank of the Rhône) itinerary passes through Switzerland's largest wine growing village, Satigny. From there, you will enjoy an exceptional view of Mont-Salève. The Entre Arve et Rhône walk introduces the “Champagne” region where a great many restaurants propose local products. Last but not least, the Entre Arve et Lac walk follows the left bank of the Rhône through charming historic villages.
Rive Droite Itinerary [https://www.myswitzerland.com/en/experiences/route/rive-droite/]
25.9 km – 6h 10 min. of walking 
Meyrin – La Plaine – Meyrin

Entre Arve et Lac Itinerary [https://www.myswitzerland.com/en/experiences/route/entre-arve-et-lac/]

data.name: Aletsch - Via ferrata on the biggest Alpine glacier
data.abstract: A via ferrata in a lakeside setting, arranged with great originality and with plenty of ironwork: ideal for scrambling up the steep rock above the water. Special highlights are the giant suspension bridge and the final Tyrolienne traverse (can be bypassed if necessary).
data.description:
Difficulty
K3-4. Technically only a moderately difficult route, and the west bank is somewhat lacking in variety. By contrast, there is plenty of variety on the inward route, with some short steep passages, traverses which force the climber slightly out from the rock face, and the two highlights mentioned above. 
Important: pay close attention to the information board at the starting-point, which explains precisely how to use the Tyrolienne traverse. After your "journey into space", first secure yourself again to the via ferrata, and only then unclip yourself from the rope pulley!

Starting-point
Blatten (1,327 m) is reached from Brig-Naters via a mountain road. It is possible to drive further, to the artificial lake of the Gibidum-Stausee (1,436 m), where there is parking.

Aletsch via ferrata
The via ferrata starts immediately from the car park above the concrete wall. Well-secured, you climb through a channel down to the water, before heading into the valley using natural and (a large number of) artificial steps, your left side attached to the wire rope, walking "au bord du lac". When the lake is full, you come very close to the (milky-green) water at several points, each time before making short climbs. The opposite bank gradually comes closer, and then you catch sight of the absolute highlight on this route, the longest via ferrata suspension bridge in the Alps. After this aerial walk high above the (ice-cold) glacier water, the route heads back along the Eastern bank. The steep rocks of the Stockflüe call for a vigorous effort, and this is followed by a few very open traverses which also force the climber slightly out from the rock face (including some with wooden safety beams); depending on the water level, the degree of clearance varies. Lastly, you have the Tyrolienne traverse, which it is now possible to bypass. One tip for this is to use the rope which pulls the pulley along as a brake.


[/imglib/USP/k_buch.jpg] Quelle:
Eugen E. Hüsler/Daniel Anker: Wandern vertikal. Die Klettersteige der Schweiz, AT Verlag, Baden 2004 

Region: Southern Bernese Alps, Rhône valley
Peak/Highest point: Stausee Gibidum (artificial lake, approx. 1480 m)
Time required: 3 hours for the circuit 
Variation in height: Negligible

data.name: Sauvabelin Park
data.abstract: On the hills above Lausanne, Sauvabelin Park is a popular destination with families and nature lovers. Anyone who scales the 302 steps up to the platform of the Tower of Sauvabelin will be rewarded with stunning panoramic views.
data.description:
Still part of the city, yet already in the countryside. Sauvabelin Park is a popular place for young and old alike to escape the hectic pace of life.

The artificial lake is surrounded by oak forests, and the animal park makes the already charming landscape even more appealing. Goats, woolly pigs, ducks, wild boar and various birds can be observed, either roaming free or in enclosures.

Don't miss the view from the 35 metre high Tour de Sauvabelin and the ‘La Pinte du Lac’ restaurant with its terrace on the lake shore.

data.name: Robert Walser Square
data.abstract: Robert Walser Square in Biel provides access to the lake and to Nidau.
data.description: Biel does not end at the station square. The thoroughfare above the station has been extended through the station passage. Robert Walser Square, opened in 2002, thereby provides access to the lake and to Nidau. The square is structured with strict rows of ash trees and surrounded by important buildings, such as the large Coop Centre, the Communication Centre, the commercial trade school and the Residenz au Lac.

data.name: Vounetz – a mountain destination with views of the Gruyère region
data.abstract: Vounetz lies above Charmey. The mountain destination is a real natural paradise, offering a wide range of things to do. No matter whether that’s panoramic hikes suitable for a range of abilities, adrenaline-fuelled zip line trips or indulging in gourmet delicacies in the restaurant at the summit – the panoramic views accompany you whatever you choose to do.
data.description:
The popular Vounetz mountain destination is situated in the heart of the Jauntal Valley, above the village of Charmey [https://www.myswitzerland.com/en/destinations/charmey/]. A cable car transports visitors to the approx. 1,610-metre peak. The view from the upper station extends out across the entire Gruyère region, with the Moléson, the Dents Vertes, the Lac de Montsalvens Reservoir and the Jaunbach Gorge in the background.

In summer, the Vounetz mountain is a real natural paradise. Various hiking trails, ranging from leisurely to challenging, invite you to discover the verdant landscapes surrounding the peak. Making the ascent up to the Vounetz by foot from Charmey is particularly worthwhile. Hikers can reach the summit in a little over two hours, where they will be rewarded with fantastic 360-degree views. The kids’ hill [https://www.charmey.ch/de/sommeraktivitaeten/kinderhuegel/], with its giant wooden toys, footprint game [https://www.charmey.ch/de/sommeraktivitaeten/fussabdruck-spiel/]and many more exciting activities offers families fun and games for all age groups.

Thrill-seekers can challenge themselves in the famous valley of the zip lines [https://www.myswitzerland.com/en/experiences/the-valley-of-the-zip-lines/]. 15 zip lines, covering a 400-metre descent, are ready to whisk you from the upper station to the middle station. And if that’s still not enough, you can also enjoy the suspension rope park in the trees [https://www.fribourgregion.ch/de/la-gruyere/outdoor-sport/charmey-aventures-parcours-in-den-baeumen/]or the via ferrata. Adrenaline is guaranteed with the Powerfan jump and the quick jumps 13 metres off the ground. A tandem or solo flight from the upper station by paraglider offers a descent of an entirely different kind.

In winter, skiers and snowboarders of all levels can let off some steam on around 30 km of ski slopes. From the nursery slopes for beginners to untouched slopes for fans of freeriding, there truly is something for everyone. Numerous snowshoe tours and ski touring routes offer more adventures off piste.

And the summit restaurant Les Dents-Vertes [https://www.myswitzerland.com/en/experiences/food-wine/restaurant/restaurant-des-dents-vertes/] is on hand to provide culinary delights. On the terrace, guests can enjoy a well-earned break, with panoramic views of the whole valley. In the warmer months (from mid-June to around mid-September), those interested in the life of cheese makers can gain insights into cheese production in the Vounetz chalet [https://www.charmey.ch/de/sommeraktivitaeten/kaeseherstellung/]. In the alp dairy, which has been home to the Piller family for over 18 years, guests can learn all about the traditions of Alpine cheese production. And, of course, this should be accompanied by a tasting of Le Gruyère d’Alpage AOP, which is produced on site.



Altitude 1,612m a.s.l. Getting there Take the train to Broc-Village, the bus to Charmey and the cable car to the Vounetz summit
Food The summit restaurant serves typical Gruyère specialities such as fondue moitié-moitié (half Gruyère, half Vacherin). Themed evenings and brunches on certain dates. Drinks and nibbles in the Le Vigousse [https://www.charmey.ch/de/restaurants/das-vigousse/] bar. Le Gruyère AOP alpine cheese or Vacherin Fribourgeois d’Alpage AOP can both be purchased from the alp dairy at the summit.

data.name: Parcours-Jeux Adventure Trail
data.abstract: Discover the animals of our region with the new concept of our playground! A thematic path, giant animal sculptures, educational panels and original plays will let you live an unforgettable time with your family! A pond, a park with deers, a picnic area belong also to the site.
data.description: Gather at the Lac des Joncs, surrounded by a wood chip path, where you can admire the rare flowers unique to this area. There are also 4 information boards and giant "charret" and "Ludo" game areas. The next step in the adventure is Rathvel, where another path takes you on a tour of the lake which has been declared a national protection site for amphibians. 4 information boards and a giant 'snakes and ladders' game area provide visitors with a fun way of learning about the animals living there.

data.name: Fun Forest
data.abstract: In Crans-Montana even the youngest visitors are given great attention. Grown-ups too can let off steam and experience the ultimate adrenaline rush.
data.description:
The Adventure Park south of Lac de la Moubra in Crans-Montana promises fun and adventure for the entire family. The trees in the forest form an ideal backdrop for this playground in the wild. 

The park consists of five courses for children above age 5. 

Children
 * Bibi (age 5 - 7)
 * Junior (at least 1.30 meters tall)
 * Discovery (from age 8 / at least 1.40 meters tall)
 * Fun (from age 10 / at least 1.50 meters tall)
 * Diabolo (from age 16)


Adults

 * Discovery
 * Fun
 * Diabolo

data.name: Gourmet panorama trail
data.abstract: Sample Fribourg specialities as you walk along one of the gourmet trails high above Lake Geneva amid the Pre-Alps – this is possible in Les Paccots.
data.description:
Two mountain restaurants and two Alpine huts cater to visitors. At Lac des Joncs, enjoy a farmer's platter with meat and cheese. Then follow the wooden 'Sentier gourmand' signs for almost two hours to sample 'Chalet soup' at the Saletta Alpine hut ... meat stock with milk, cream, four vegetables, macaroni and melted cheese. Your host Raoul Colliard is world famous: at Montreal's 'Festival des lumières' in 2015, he prepared well over 1000 fondues. 

The next gourmet stop is only half an hour’s walk away – Le Vuipay snack bar, where hikers can sample delicious cream macaroni. You’ll then begin a steep descent to discover Les Rosalys restaurant and its “cooked-wine ice cream”, another speciality of Fribourg.

data.name: Free winter play area, Tracouet
data.abstract: The Lake Tracouet Arena is without doubt the perfect place for those who are just starting to learn to ski. Specialist ski schools and child-friendly facilities ensure that the little ones will enjoy their first experiences in the snow.
data.description:
The beginners’ park provides an ideal practice area and is located right next to Lake Tracouet, which freezes over in the winter, near the upper station of the gondola lift of the same name. Accompanied by their parents or their ski instructor, children can make their first attempts at skiing in the snow in a safe environment. Young guests are welcome to use the extensive facilities free of charge.
Exact location / area: Tracouet, Nendaz (2200m above sea level) 
How to get there: Mountain railway 
Infrastructure; Magic carpet / conveyor belt, Pinocchio lift / lift for beginners, snow carousel, fitness circuit, snowtubing 
Children’s ski racing: Yes 
Size: No details 
Minimum age: from 3 years 
Supervision by children’s ski instructors: No 
Personal use without supervision: Yes, subject to charges 
Introductory sessions: No 
Restaurant with view of the children’s winter play area: Bar du Lac

data.name: On the trail of beavers
data.abstract: In the Grande Cariçaie, some spots are known by experts for their frequent visits from beavers. Why not spend an evening on their trail?
data.description:
Accompanied by a biologist, beaver spotters head to these creatures’ favourite spots with their eyes fixed on the marshes, hoping to encounter one along the way. Armed with torches, night-time visitors must be patient and calm if they want to come away with happy memories of seeing Europe's largest native rodent.

For more information and bookings, click here [https://fribourg.ch/en/estavayer-payerne/events/on-the-trail-of-the-beavers/][https://www.estavayer-payerne.ch/fr/P59026/sur-la-trace-des-castors]

data.name: Crossing the Great St. Bernard Hill
data.abstract: The thousand-year-old hospice in Great St. Bernard is the point of departure for this hike.
data.description:
The dogs descended from the legendary Barry welcome visitors in their usual friendly manner. The museum and the precious hospice are a gentle start, before going in the general direction of Italy for a few kilometres and returning to Switzerland via the three mirror-like lakes offering spectacular reflections of the surrounding mountains. The descent into the village of La Fouly provides a touch of colour as the wild flowers spring up in Val Ferret. Tasting alpine cheeses and the lively atmosphere in the village restaurants will revive you a little and prepare you for your return journey.

How to get there:
Take the TMR SA bus for the Great St. Bernard hill. The return leg is by TMR SA bus from La Fouly, which will take you back to the starting point in Orsieres. Orsieres is on the Great St. Bernard Express line.
